title: Property taxes and home insurance in bankruptcy
question: I have not paid property taxes for two years. I think they are up to $20000 now. If I file bankruptcy, do I name the tax collector as a creditor? I am still within the timeframe to make tax payments and I do not have any tax liens.

In order to keep the house you will need to have do a chapter 13 bankruptcy, and as such you would need enough income to pay the current house payment, your bills, and have enough left over to fund a plan that would cover your past due secured debts including property taxes and house payments. If you can not afford your house payment then it is unlikely that you will be able to afford the past due secured debt that would have to be paid through the chapter 13 bankruptcy plan.

You say "my unemployment income (currently on appeal) might not be able to cover the payments, taxes and insurance". It sounds like the only way you are going to be able to keep your house is if you can somehow lower the payments. It appears that you need a loan modification to keep the house. You need to talk to your lender. A chapter 7 won't allow you to lower your mortgage payments. But it will allow you to get rid of your unsecured debts which might make paying your mortgage easier. A chapter 13 will allow you to pay off the past due amounts (if any) over the life of your plan. But the court does not have the power to change the terms of your mortgage. Check HAMP and see if you qualify for a loan modification.

You may WANT to keep your home, but if you can not make payments, BK is not going to help.

You have $20K in back taxes in 2 years, that is about $900K home purchase value or current assessed value.

If you file C7 while in arrears, the Lender will seek a relief of stay and that will be granted, they will foreclose.

If you file C13, you must start making current contract payments and arrears and taxes and insurance within 30 days....and if you can't then they(Lender) will seek relief...?

You need immediate professional help.

You must list all of your debts in the bankruptcy case including the tax collector. If you want to keep your house you will need to file a Chapter 13 or Chapter 11 bankruptcy case (depending on the amount of debt you have, but more likely a Chapter 13) to pay bring the taxes and the mortgage (if applicable) current. If your intent is to let the property go, you can achieve that through a Chapter 7, 11 or 13 case. You should check with a bankruptcy attorney before deciding on the type of case that is right for you. If you file a Chapter 7 and let the house go, the taxes will be discharged along with the mortgage. If you file a Chapter 13 or 11, you will have to pay some of the debt back even if you are letting the house go in most cases. Good luck.

You asked, "do I name the tax collector as a creditor?"
Yes, you do. List the County Treasurer on Schedule D.

If you haven't been paying the mortgage, then what's your intent regarding your property? If you just want to surrender the house, and if you're eligible for Chapter 7 relief in order to discharge your personal liability for your dischargeable debts (see a lawyer!), then you can go ahead with a Chapter 7 filing.

If you want to keep your house, then you may need to consider a Chapter 13 filing. That's because if you file Chapter 7 but you're behind on your mortgage payments, the creditor might pursue a Motion for Relief from Stay, and obtain a Court order that allows the creditor to go ahead with a foreclosure sale. Another possibility is that the creditor will just wait until the Chapter 7 case is over and closed. Even after receiving an order of discharge, the creditor can still foreclose on your house if you're behind on your mortgage payments. That's because a Chapter 7 filing does not "eliminate" mortgage arrears. Your personal liability would be discharged, but a mortgage (plus the arrears) would remain as a secured claim against your home.

In Chapter 13, you can propose a payment plan to cure the mortgage arrears over a period of 36 to 60 months. If you have more than 1 loan against your house, you may be able to do "lien stripping" in Chapter 13 to remove the junior loans.

Regarding home insurance, a bankruptcy filing will protect you as far as your personal liability is concerned. However, a bankruptcy filing may affect your ability to get affordable insurance, if that's what you're trying to ask, due to the impact that a bankruptcy filing will have on your credit score.

You will need a consultation with an attorney to cover these issues, plus many other issues.

The taxes and other debts have to be listed in the bankruptcy. If you want to keep the house they will have to be repaid in a chapter 13. If you give the house up and file bankruptcy you will not be responsible for the taxes.

Chapter 7 permits the debtor to get rid of all of their unsecured debt without having to make payments to that debt. It is not a good choice for people who are behind on their mortgage and want to save their house from foreclosure. It is an excellent choice if you want speed and simplicity.

You must qualify for a 7. The tests are income versus ALLOWABLE expenses (term of art...need a lawyer) "liquidation" (do you have equity in property that is not protected by an exemption (law stuff again) and the "means test"...one of the stupidest things Congress has ever thought up (and I am a conservative Republican) which asks are you an above or below median (half above/half below) income household.

Chapter 13 is a bankruptcy where you are required to make a monthly payment for 36 or up to 60 months. The basis of the payment is never unsecured debt. It is affected by the tests outlined above. Filing this bankruptcy will stop a foreclosure and allow you to repay the mortgage arrears at zero percent interest.
